[ç›®]
Pictogram ( è±¡å½¢ ) â€“ human eye, now rotated 90 degrees. Compare the Egyptian hieroglyph ğ“¹ .
See also ç›´ , è¦‹ , é  , å¤ , é¢ , è‡£ and the earlier versions of è¦ . The eye is not rotated in the character ğ¢›³ , æ›¼ , çª , and çœ” (used in è¤± ).
Sometimes it depicts a web ( ç½‘ ) through its variant ç½’ , e.g., è²· , ç½µ , ç½ª , è©ˆ (used in ç½° ) and ç¾… (> ç½— ). Unrelated to é¼ , è² , and çœŸ .

[ä¸”]
Pictogram ( è±¡å½¢ ). Multiple interpretations:
â€¢ A stone altar â€“ original form of ç¥– ( OC *Ê”saËÊ” ).
â€¢ A sacrificial vessel used for chopping and holding meat, as viewed from above ( Wang, 1923 ) â€“ original form of ä¿ ( OC *Ê”sraÊ” ).
â€¢ An erect penis, the symbol of the male ancestor ( Guo Moruo, 1931 ) â€“ original form of ç¥– ( OC *Ê”saËÊ” ).
In the oracle bones and bronze inscriptions, this character was commonly used as ç¥– ( OC *Ê”saËÊ” ); usage as ä¿ ( OC *Ê”sraÊ” ) is not attested until the Warring States period in the bamboo script. See also the original version of æŸ¥ .

[ç¥–]
Phono-semantic compound ( å½¢è² / å½¢å£° , OC *Ê”saËÊ” ): semantic ç¤º + phonetic ä¸” ( OC *sÊ°jaËÊ”, *Ê”sa ) . Specialization of ä¸” . See there for more.
